title: London's Royal Academy unlocks Matisse's studio
description:
(1 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
London's Royal Academy of Arts is unlocking French artist Henri Matisse's studio.
Its new exhibit, which opens Saturday (5 August), shows how Matisse's treasured items often served as both inspiration and subject matter for many of his famed works.
STORYLINE:
French artist Henri Matisse once said; 'My life is between the walls of my studio.' Now, art fans can step inside.
London's Royal Academy of Arts is unveiling a new exhibit that shows Matisse in the studio.
It's claimed to be the first exhibit to explore how the artist's treasured collection of objects inspired his work and often became the subject matter.
It includes around 35 objects, accompanied by 65 Matisse artworks.
"We hope that walking through the exhibition you'll really get an intimate sense of the studio process," says curator Helen Burnham.
"Looking at the actual objects, how they appear in his work and on a more conceptual level how they affected his sense of composition, colour, design and the evolution of his art, towards the end of his life even."
Matisse's eclectic collection ranges from Chinese porcelain vases to African masks.
At times he used studio props, such as North African furniture, wall hangings and metal work.
Many items on show are being loaned from the Musee Matisse in Nice, France.
"He did actually call them actors," says Burnham.
"He said; 'The object is an actor. It can have a part in many different plays and play many different roles.'"
The exhibit features this 19th century Venetian chair, it served as inspiration for several works, including 'Venetian Chair with Fruit' from 1942.
When Matisse found the chair, he wrote to friend Louis Aragon; 'I have at last found the object for which I've been longing for a whole year.'
"This Rocaille chair, he bought much later in his life, and he wrote to his friend, the writer and resistance fighter Louis Aragon about the chair, the almost passionate response to this chair, so much that Aragon called it Matisse's gigolo," says Burnham.
Elsewhere, this Andalusian blown glass vase served as inspiration for two paintings, Matisse interpreted its curved green shape like the voluptuous curves of a woman.
"To him, when he was starting out and he couldn't afford to pay a model," explains art critic Estelle Lovatt.
"He would seek out by travelling the world, he would seek out the most voluptuous, curvaceous, vases and jugs that he could find, because they're very reminiscent of the organic, of the feminine, of the female form."
In later life, Matisse experimented with large, colourful cut-outs. 
He repeatedly spoke about Chinese artists in relation to his own search for simplified signs. 
A selection of cut-outs are displayed next to these Chinese porcelain vases.
"This exhibition is unique for giving us something that no other Matisse exhibition has ever given us before," says Lovatt.
"For example, there's so many works here that I have never seen, and it's so exciting to see his paintings literally come to life. 
"The paintings, and the drawings, and the prints, and the cut-outs, are hanging next to the materials that he touched, and sat on, and loved, loved as much as the people around him. 
"And this is what makes this exhibition unique is that it gives us the full, 3D picture of him."
Matisse died in 1954 at the age of 84. 
'Matisse in the Studio' runs 5 August - 12 November at London's Royal Academy of Arts.
